coredata.dc:description: Cu-Ni-TiO2 showed a distinct surface plasmon resonance (SPR) due to a synergetic interaction between Ni and Cu resulted in a suitable electron-hole separation consequently the charge carriers were easily transferred to TiO2 surface. The Cu-Ni bimetallic alloy particles with the localized SPR demonstrated the ability to absorb the wide range of wavelength (400-800 nm) in the visible light. The SPR band red-shifted from UV window to near-infrared and covered the entire UV-visible light region stemmed to avail full advantage of sunlight in the photocatalytic H2O splitting. The bimetallic 2Cu-5Ni/TiO2 catalyst showed visible light H2O splitting under solar light with a H2 yield ca. 0.20 mmol g-1 h-1 in the absence of a sacrificial agent and ∼ 35.4 mmol g−1 h−1, while H2O + CH3OH mixture was used. The SPR behaviour of Cu-Ni alloy particles was explained by H2-TPR, N2O titration, XRD, TEM, UV-DRS, XPS, PL and Raman spectroscopy.

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: Cu-Ni-TiO2 showed a distinct surface plasmon resonance (SPR) due to a synergetic interaction between Ni and Cu resulted in a suitable electron-hole separation consequently the charge carriers were easily transferred to TiO2 surface. The Cu-Ni bimetallic alloy particles with the localized SPR demonstrated the ability to absorb the wide range of wavelength (400-800 nm) in the visible light. The SPR band red-shifted from UV window to near-infrared and covered the entire UV-visible light region stemmed to avail full advantage of sunlight in the photocatalytic H2O splitting. The bimetallic 2Cu-5Ni/TiO2 catalyst showed visible light H2O splitting under solar light with a H2 yield ca. 0.20 mmol g-1 h-1 in the absence of a sacrificial agent and ∼ 35.4 mmol g−1 h−1, while H2O + CH3OH mixture was used. The SPR behaviour of Cu-Ni alloy particles was explained by H2-TPR, N2O titration, XRD, TEM, UV-DRS, XPS, PL and Raman spectroscopy.

ce:section.ce:para: H2 has been considered as a clean energy carrier and its production from renewable sources by utilization of solar energy (infinite source) and water in presence of a semiconductor via photocatalytic water splitting showed a significant research interest compared to conventional H2 production from finite fossil resources [1–2]. Mostly the photocatalytic setups require sacrificial reagents (inorganic and/or organic) which could minimise the recombination of charge carriers (e- - h+) by capturing the photo generated holes and in some case can act as proton donors for the enhanced hydrogen production rates. Plenty of articles appeared in the last few decades on the exploration of different types of photocatalysts to generate H2 by solar energy driven water splitting for example nitride, sulphide and oxide based catalysts [3–6]. TiO2 has been widely used semiconductor photo catalyst owing to its exceptional physicochemical properties and it shows the photocatalytic activity only when irradiated by UV radiation due to its higher band gap (3.2 eV). The valance and conduction band gap required for H2 production by splitting of water is minimum 1.23 eV. However, TiO2 is ineffective for hydrogen production from water splitting due to the fast recombination of holes and electrons, which results to the formation of water.

In order to overcome this speedy recombination, efforts have been made to increase H2 production over modified TiO2 catalysts [7–10]. The poor separation efficiency of the electron-hole pairs led to lower photocatalytic performance that limits the use of TiO2 as such for H2O splitting and for the various other solar applications [11]. Tay et al have observed the multiple hetero-junctions created while g-C3N4 was coupled with multi-phase TiO2 consequently improved H2 production rates [12]. The metal doped TiO2 catalysts have also been employed for the improved H2 yields by photocatalytic water splitting [13,14]. Doping of metals to TiO2 results in the separation of photo generated charge carrier pairs and offers the active sites for H2 generation is one of the most successful approaches to enhance the catalytic performance of TiO2. Of the many, platinum and other noble metals have been explored for H2O splitting under solar light irradiation [15]. However, in view of scare supply of noble metals and also due to high cost, it is necessary to explore the inexpensive metal based TiO2 catalysts [16].

In general, bimetallic catalysts exhibit improved catalytic performance when compared with their monometallic catalysts [17–20]. Among the base metals loaded TiO2, the surface plasmonic resonance (SPR) effect of Ni and/or Cu based bimetallic photocatalysts have attracted much attention, since they represent a class of favourable photocatalysts which are playing a vital role. In thermo-catalytic processes the Ni-Cu bimetallic catalysts have been effective for improved yields in the CH4 reforming, CO2 hydrogenation processes and CO free H2 production by catalytic CH4 cracking over Ni/SiO2 and Ni-Cu/TiO2, Cu-Ni/SiO2. The Ni-Cu nanoparticles are being explored in various important processes such as methane decomposition [21], ethanol steam reforming [22], oxidation of methanol [23], water-gas shift reaction [24,25], magnetic applications [26], and also in hyperthermia applications for tumour treatments [27], which have shown improved catalytic activity and selectivity compared to their monometallic counterparts.

In the present study, we have identified the bimetallic Cu-Ni alloy nanoparticles decorated on TiO2 exhibited remarkably improved visible light photo catalytic activity (fourfold) when compared to their monometallic counterparts in H2O splitting. The superior performance of Cu-Ni alloy particles was attributed to surface plasmon behavior of the Cu-Ni/TiO2 photocatalyst. The physicochemical properties of the fresh and some of the used (recovered after reaction) catalysts was rationalized by using ultraviolet-visible diffuse reflectance spectroscopy (UV-DRS), powder X-ray diffraction (XRD), X – ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), cyclic voltammetry (CV), H2-temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR), Fourier transform infrared spectra (FTIR), electron microscopy (TEM), Raman spectroscopy and photoluminescence (PL) spectroscopic techniques and photocurrent measurements. The degree of reduction of the fresh mono (Ni/TiO2 and/or Cu/TiO2) and bimetallic Cu-Ni samples and used catalysts was examined by N2O titration method. The main objective of this work was, firstly to synthesize the plasmonic photocatalysts, particularly, Cu-Ni alloy nanoparticles for H2O splitting by harvesting the visible light in presence of sunlight. Secondly, examination of the synthesized catalyst samples using a variety of characterization techniques to rationalize the structure-activity relationship. Finally, a detailed investigation on the nano sized Cu-Ni alloy particles formation and their influence on the localized surface plasmon resonance (LSPR) phenomenon in the visible light which was illustrated by surface and bulk properties of the Cu-Ni alloy nano species.
TiO2-P25 is procured from Degussa Co. (Germany). The analytical grade Cu(II) nitrate hexahydrate and Ni(II) nitrate hexahydrate were of analytical grade purchased from Sigma Aldrich.

The mono Cu, Ni and/or binary Cu-Ni dopedTiO2 (P25) catalysts were prepared by a simple wet impregnation and co-impregnation methods respectively. For this purpose, required amounts of Cu(NO3)2.6H2O and/or Ni(NO3)2.6H2O aqueous salt solutions were added to the TiO2 to give the corresponding mol% of respective metals. The varied amounts of Cu (0.5, 1, 2 and 3 mol%) with constant Ni loading of about 5 mol% were prepared by co-impregnation on TiO2. All the catalysts were dried at 80 ᴼC for about 12 h. The dried solids were calcined in the temperature range 350-750 ᴼC. The prepared catalysts were denoted as 2Cu/TiO2, 5Ni/TiO2, 0.5Cu-5Ni/TiO2, 1Cu-5Ni/TiO2, 2Cu-5Ni/TiO2 and 3Cu-5Ni/TiO2.

The fresh and some of the used (recovered after reaction) samples were examined by using different characterization techniques. N2O pulse chemisorption is a very well-known technique for the measurement of metal surface area particularly for Cu and Ni [28]. For N2O titration the fresh calcined sample was reduced at 450 °C for 1 h (using 4.97% H2/Ar) followed by flushing the catalyst with pure helium gas flow for 1 h at 450 °C. In the following step under helium gas flow, the temperature was set to 90 °C at which the pulse titration experiments were conducted by passing the pure N2O (purity 99.995%). The N2O pulse injections were terminated as soon as the N2O decomposition saturated, which was confirmed by gas chromatography - thermal conductivity detector (GC-TCD) [29]. In case of used catalysts (recovered after 10 h of reaction), the catalysts were vacuum dried at 400 °C for 1 h, before injecting N2O under similar protocol mentioned above. The PL patterns of the catalysts were analysed with Spectrofluorometer (FLUORO MAX 4 P) by using the excitation wavelength of 330 nm. The CV analysis of the samples recorded with a BAS 100B at a scan rate of 100 mV/s with 0.1 M KCl as the supporting electrolyte, a Pt wire as the working and counter electrodes, and Ag/AgCl as the reference electrode. The H2-TPR patterns were recorded in quartz reactor, which is connected to a GC-TCD. The details of the other characterisation techniques such as powder XRD, BET-SA, XPS, FT-IR, HRTEM, UV-Vis DRS were reported in electronic supporting material (ESI). Selected samples were characterized by different techniques and all the samples were examined for photocatalytic H2O splitting activities for hydrogen production.

The photocatalytic activities were performed under both natural and artificial light irradiations. Solar source intensity was estimated with digital lux meter and the average light intensity was recorded approximately 1,30,000 Lux. In a typical method required amount of calcined catalyst was placed in 100 ml quartz made vertical reactor containing 45 ml of water and in some cases methanol was used as a sacrificial reagent. The reactor was purged several times with N2 (99.99%) and then sealed with silicone rubber septum. Initially the reaction mixture along with the catalyst was stirred for 30 min without light source, followed by exposing the mixture to solar and/or artificial light irradiation. During the reaction, the evolved H2 was analysed at regular intervals with GC-TCD (Chemito Instruments) by passing N2 gas as carrier gas using a Molecular Sieve 5A packed column.

The XRD patterns of the TiO2, 2Cu/TiO2, 5Ni/TiO2 and 2Cu-5Ni/TiO2 samples showed strong signals due to TiO2 phase (Fig. S1) [30,31]. The diffraction lines corresponding to NiO and CuO phases are not clearly seen. Either they may be finely dispersed or their crystallite size may be below the detection limit. The crystalline phases in the used (catalyst recovered after the reaction termed as used) 2Cu-5Ni/TiO2 catalyst showed the formation of Cu-Ni alloy; though the peak intensities are very weak, we found the Ni-rich Cu-Ni alloy formation (Fig. S2). The crystalline phases in the used (catalyst recovered after the reaction termed as used) 2Cu-5Ni/TiO2 catalyst showed the formation of Cu-Ni alloy; though the peak intensities are very weak, we found the Ni-rich Cu-Ni alloy formation (Fig. S2). The profile of the used 2Cu-5Ni/TiO2 showed weak signals due to Cu-Ni alloy phase at 2θ = 43.4 ° (Fig. S2) enabled by mild photo reduction of oxides to microcrystalline alloy under light irradiation [32,33]. Cu-Ni alloy formation is quite feasible due to similar ionic radius and electro negativity of both Ni and Cu [34]. Similar findings are reported by several researchers on the partial Cu-Ni alloy formation with prominent shoulder peaks indicative of (111) and (200) planes of Cu-Ni alloy [35–38]. The shoulder peak at 2θ = 43.4 ° indicated two peaks overlapping patterns of two distinct Cu2O-Ni and Cu-Ni alloy phases [20,39,40]. Such phase segregation behaviour of Cu-Ni interacted with TiO2 and other supports are in good correlation with earlier reports [41].

UV Vis - DR spectra of different Cu, Ni and bimetallic Cu-Ni doped TiO2 are displayed in Figs. S3–S6. The mono metallic Ni/TiO2 and Cu/TiO2 photocatalysts demonstrated a strong UV-vis band at around 350 nm, which is ascribed to the excitation of O 2p electron to Ti 3d level. The absorption band of monometallic samples exhibited a weak red shift (towards higher wavelength) when compared to P25 spectrum. Dozzi et al reported that the absorption signal appeared in the wavelength range 400-500 nm, could be attributed to the interfacial charge transfer (IFCT) of electrons, which arises due to the charge transfer of electrons from TiO2 valence band (VB) to the decorated Cu(II) sites [42]. In contrast, Chung et al reported that the absorption band was shifted to visible region over Ni-TiO2photocatalyst [43]. An elongated band edge of TiO2 in the visible region (725-738 nm) occurred upon doping of nickel and/or copper species in to the TiO2 creating additional energy levels in the TiO2 matrix. The UV-vis spectra showed a band at 240 nm is assigned to the ligand to metal charge transfer (LMCT) in all the samples (Fig. 1 ). More pronounced shift of absorption band edge toward visible region is observed upon doping Ni and/or Cu (Figs. S1–S5). Similar observations found by Bashiri et al; upon doping of Ni2+ and Cu2+ species into the TiO2 lattice [44]. The band gap energies of fresh nickel and/or copper co-impregnated TiO2 samples are lower than the P25-TiO2 (Figs. S3–S6). All the Cu doped TiO2 photocatalysts exhibited strong absorption band at around 350 nm. Compared to TiO2, the absorption onset of the supported photocatalysts slightly shifted towards the longer wavelength gives rise to a decrease in the band gap. The Cu doped photocatalysts showed an extra-large absorption band between 400 to 800 nm. The band edge of TiO2 is slightly expanded into the (large bathochromic shift) visible region as a result additional energy levels created by the copper in the band gap of TiO2. With increasing copper loading over TiO2, the band gap energy values are decreased from 3.2 eV to a minimum value of 2.56 eV as shown in Fig. S3a (inset).

The Ni doped TiO2 exhibited strong absorption over the wide range of wavelength and for TiO2 300-450 nm is observed. The reason for this large bathochromic shift in optical energy gap is explained due to the fact that the energy level for nickel lies below the conduction band edge (Ecb) and above the valence band edge (Evb) of TiO2. Introduction of such energy levels in the band gap induces the bathochromic shift in the band gap transition and the visible light absorption through a charge transfer between a dopant and CB and/or VB. In the Ni doped samples the band at 720 nm arises from octahedral Ni2+ in bulk NiO and the bands at 598 and 636 nm are indication of Ni2+ in tetrahedral sites which are absent (Fig. S6). With increasing nickel loading the band gap energies are decreased from 3.2 eV to a minimum value of 2.56 eV (Fig. S4 inset).

The TEM image of used 2Cu-5Ni/TiO2 photocatalyst; show randomly distributed particles with irregular shape (Fig. 2 A). The HRTEM image revealed distinct dark spots which are probably due to Cu-Ni alloy nanoparticles (Fig. 2B). The lattice fringes can be seen in 0.32 nm and 0.35 nm, which correspond to the (110) and (101) planes and these are attributed to rutile and anatase TiO2 phase. The selected-area electron diffraction (SAED) image and energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) mapping results (Fig. 2), clearly verified the close contact between the Cu-Ni alloy nanoparticles and the TiO2. Moreover, the crystallinity of the Cu-Ni was verified by the SAED image (Fig. 2C); the distinct rings are ascribed to the corresponding diffraction planes. Since the Cu-Ni alloy nanoparticles were on the TiO2, EDS mapping was conducted to investigate the specific elemental distributions of Cu, Ni, Ti, and O. Fig. 2(D) shows the dark field TEM image (HAADF) to investigate the distribution of Ni, Cu, Ti, and O elements of 2Cu-5Ni/TiO2. Fig. 2(E) shows the combined image of colour mapping of Ni, Cu, Ti, and O elements of 2Cu-5Ni/TiO2. Fig. 2(F–I) illustrate the colour mapping of individual Ni, Cu, Ti, and O elements from the selected area. As observed in Fig. 2J, the EDS mapping profiles further confirm the presence of Cu-Ni alloy on the surface of TiO2. Therefore, the Cu-Ni alloy on the TiO2 plays a significant role in determining the mobility of the charge carriers, which improves the photocatalytic activity of 2Cu-5Ni/TiO2.

Raman spectroscopy was employed to identify the bands ascribed to TiO2 structural information. All the samples exhibited prominent Raman shifts around 148, 392, 505 and 629 cm-1 (Fig. 3 ) which indicate the typical TiO2 anatase phase and is consistent with XRD results (Fig. S1). These peaks are assigned to Eg, B1g, A1g and Eg modes of the anatase TiO2 phase [45]. The spectra show a shift in peak of Eg band caused by symmetric stretching vibration of O-Ti-O in TiO2 of Cu/TiO2 and Ni/TiO2 samples. The peak intensities doubled upon increasing the Cu loading from 0.5 – 3.0 mol% on Ni/TiO2 catalysts and the bands were drifted towards lower wavenumber. Such phenomenon is obvious while defect sites are increased in the TiO2 according to Tian et al from their findings on increased ratio of highly active {001} facets in TiO2 [46]. Notably, in fact, O-Ti-O symmetric stretching vibrations resulted in appearance of Eg band in Raman spectra of TiO2 (Eg bands appeared at 144 and 636 cm−1), whilst the O-Ti-O symmetric bending vibration causes the appearance of B1g band and corresponding band can be identified at 392 cm−1, and the O-Ti-O antisymmetric bending vibration resulted in presence of A1g band at 514 cm−1 in Raman spectra of TiO2 [47]. It can be seen that the peak intensities are relatively higher at higher Cu loadings. The higher intensity of these signals represents the enhancement of oxygen vacancies on the TiO2 surface which is clearly visualised from the patterns that the signals become stronger as the Cu loading is increased. The significant difference in the peak intensity, peak broadening and peak shift confirms the structural and morphological differences occurred due to an increased loading of Cu on TiO2. Parker et al made a similar observation when the bismuth content is increased from 1.0 to 2.0 wt% due to increased crystalline defects within the TiO2 frame work [48].

ce:section.ce:section-title: H2-temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) and N2O titration
ce:section.ce:para: The reducibility of the catalysts is estimated by H2-temperature programmed reduction measurements and the patterns of the mono (5Ni/TiO2 and/or 2Cu/TiO2) and Cu-Ni/TiO2 bimetallic samples are reported in Fig. 4 A.

The mono metallic (Cu and/or Ni) catalysts showed single stage reduction profile and the bimetallic sample (2Cu-5Ni/TiO2) demonstrated three reduction signals around 245, 290 and 455 °C. The 5Ni/TiO2 displayed (Fig. 4Aa) the signal at 475 °C ascribed to the reduction of Ni2+ species present on TiO2 [49]. Whereas the 2Cu/TiO2 (Fig. 4Ab) sample showed a peak at 275 °C which is ascribed to reduction of CuO particles present on TiO2 [50]. In the low temperature region (Fig. 4Ac) two reduction signals are observed at 245 and 290 °C, over 2Cu-5Ni/TiO2 which is attributed to highly dispersed Cu2+ species while the signal at 290 °C is originated from interacted CuO-NiO species [51]. The broadness of the signal appeared in 2Cu/TiO2 (∼275 °C) can be explained due to strongly interacted copper oxide species with TiO2 to some extent. It is noteworthy to mention that the characteristic reduction signal of NiO (475 °C) in 5Ni/TiO2 is shifted to low temperature (455 °C) on 2Cu-5Ni/TiO2. This shift in Tmax is explained based on the Cu activated hydrogen, resulted to decrease the Tmax of the Ni oxide particles. Such a phenomenon is quite possible only when oxides of Cu and Ni particles are interacted together [52,53].

TPR patterns of the photo reduced (recovered after 10 h of reaction) samples exhibited reduction signals with very low intensities compared to their TPR of fresh samples (Fig. 4A, B). The reduction signals are appeared at Tmax ∼ 400 °C (5Ni/TiO2), 190, 222 °C (2Cu/TiO2) and peaks around 220 °C, 325 °C (2Cu-5Ni/TiO2) suggesting not only a decrease in Tmax but also a dramatic decrease in H2 uptakes by 45 – 55% (Table 1 ). A drastic decrease in Tmax of the photo reduced samples is in concomitant with in situ reduction of oxides of copper-nickel species during the course of photocatalytic reaction. The deconvoluted pattern of photo reduced 2Cu-5Ni/TiO2 sample exhibited broad reduction signal with several shoulder peaks represents the existence of partly reduced Ni and/or Cu oxide species at different levels (Fig. S7). Reduction signal appeared in the 200 °C region is due to Cu2O-Ni interacted particles and the peak appeared in the 325 °C region (Fig. 4Bc′) is ascribed to the reduction of copper-nickel interacted species [33]. The H2 and N2O uptakes on the fresh and photo reduced catalysts are reported in Table 1. The extent of reduction of surface metal oxides during the photocatalytic reaction is estimated by N2O titration. The N2O uptakes of the photo reduced catalysts are lower than their corresponding fresh form (Table 1). An enhanced N2O decomposition is observed over Cu loaded Ni/TiO2 catalysts. From the TPR and N2O titration studies, it can be concluded that there exists and interaction between Ni and Cu on TiO2.

Charge carrier transfer or/and migration and their trapping rates in the photocatalyst can be estimated using Photoluminescence (PL) emission spectroscopy. It is a known fact that the recombination of the photo induced charge carriers resulted in the emission of photoluminescence, which in general proportional to the recombination rate of charge carriers [54,55]. The PL spectra show emission features at 403 nm, 431 nm and a shoulder around 467 nm (Fig. 5 ). The peak around 403 nm is originated from the free exciton emission of TiO2, whereas the charge transfer transition from Ti3+ to the O2- in [TiO6]8- shows its characteristic peak at 431 nm. The shoulder peak at 467 nm is due to the surface state Ti4+−OH species [56]. The PL intensity is drastically decreased upon loading of Cu and/or Ni on TiO2 (Fig. 5). The decrease in intensity is occurred due to severe quenching of metal oxide species which are decorated on TiO2. Melvin et al have observed the similar phenomenon over Au, Pt and Au-Pt deposited on TiO2 catalyst where the decrease in the emission intensity was 2-3 orders of magnitude [57]. The PL spectra demonstrated the emission features of TiO2 (407, 434, 467 nm), 2Cu/TiO2 (407, 433 and 469 nm), 5Ni/TiO2 (411, 437 and 466 nm) and bimetallic 2Cu-5Ni-TiO2 (407, 428 and 467 nm) samples (Fig. 5). The Cu-Ni loaded TiO2 sample showed suppressed PL intensity (403, 426 and 467 nm) than the bare TiO2. The Cu-Ni alloy species seems to alter the electronic transitions, resulted in the improvement in the separation of the photo induced charge carriers (electrons and holes) on the catalyst surface as was evidenced from the lower PL intensity. In general, presence of a high ratio of surface defects and/or surface oxygen vacancies leads to the localisation of valence and conduction bands [58]. Therefore, these factors are responsible for a decrease in PL intensity in the photo reduced samples (Fig. 5 dotted line). Such oxygen vacancies can greatly influence the photo induced charge behaviour consequently enhanced photocatalytic performance would occur. In parenthesis the PL intensity of used mono metallic Cu and/or Ni and bimetallic (Cu-Ni) loaded TiO2 is estimated to be ca. 20% decrease while compared with the fresh catalysts explaining a remarkable enhancement in the charge separation of electron and hole occurred in the presence of Ni-Cu alloy nanoparticles present on the titania surface (dotted spectra Fig. 5). The photo-electrochemical investigation is also performed to study the transportation charge carriers and their separation efficiency.

The repeated on and off photocurrent measurements conducted over various catalysts under simulated sunlight and the corresponding on/off cycles are represented in Fig. 6 . The obtained results showed when the sunlight is irradiated; all the samples displayed the response of transient photocurrent while there is no response in dark conditions. When the light is turned on, the photocurrent is increased to certain level and it comes down to zero as soon as the light was turned off, indicating the consistency in the measurements. Miao et al noticed a high photocurrent in Cu/TiO2 photocatalyst owing to the photogenerated charge separation consequently a higher photocatalytic activity was obtained [59]. The 2Cu-5Ni/TiO2 catalyst demonstrated a higher transient surface photocurrent compared to bare P25 TiO2 and mono metallic 2Cu/TiO2 and 5Ni/TiO2 catalysts, representing the enhanced migration and separation of photogenerated electron-hole pairs on bimetallic 2Cu-5Ni/TiO2 catalyst, consequently improved hydrogen yields were obtained. These results are further validated from the cyclic voltammetry analysis of the fresh and used catalysts which showed a change in redox potential in Cu-Ni/TiO2 with respect to P25-TiO2 (Fig. S8). The shift in redox potential is a clear indication due to the presence of Cu-Ni alloy species [60].

In the absence of a sacrificial agent under natural sunlight the photocatalytic water splitting activities over various Ni loaded TiO2 catalysts demonstrated a maximum of 16.0 μmoles g-1 h-1 of H2 on 5Ni/TiO2 (Table 2 ). A series of Cu modified 5Ni/TiO2 catalysts were prepared and tested for H2 production and the results are reported in Table 2. The activity data shows increase in hydrogen yield over all the Cu-Ni/TiO2 catalysts. The optimized (metal loadings such as Ni and/or Cu) catalysts that is 5 mol%Ni/TiO2 and 2 mol%Cu/TiO2 exhibited lower hydrogen yields than the bimetallic catalysts. Meanwhile, when all the catalysts tested under visible light; the hydrogen yields are found to be half of the quantities obtained under natural sunlight in presence of CH3OH. An interesting point to be noted here is that the H2 yields are more or less same in presence of CH3OH, when the tests were carried out in natural and artificial sunlight. Under similar experimental conditions, the Cu loaded TiO2 samples showed slightly better H2 yields than the Ni/TiO2 catalysts. The optimized 2Cu-5Ni/TiO2 sample has been further evaluated to establish the CH3OH concentration, on the rate of H2 production.

Under the reaction conditions the TiO2 (P25) did not show promising H2O splitting activity. On the other hand, in presence of both natural and artificial sunlight, 2Cu and 5Ni supported on TiO2 samples demonstrated reasonably good H2 yields. Whilst the bimetallic Cu-Ni/TiO2 catalysts demonstrated higher H2 yields compared to their respective mono metallic counter parts. The visible light photocatalytic hydrogen yields are found to be low compared to the natural and artificial solar light irradiations. These results thus emphasize the SPR effect of Ni, Cu and Ni-Cu/TiO2 catalysts when examined under natural and artificial sunlight. The stability of 2Cu-5Ni/TiO2 catalyst tested for 3 cycles showed a consistent H2 production rate (Fig. S9). The 2Cu-5Ni/TiO2 catalyst studied at varied catalyst load in the range from 2.5-20 mg using CH3OH + H2O mixture under natural and artificial light irradiation showed an enormous effect on H2 yields (Fig. S10). The optimum H2 evolution rate of 35.4 mmol g-1 is observed using an amount of ∼5 mg catalyst and further increase in the catalyst amount led to decrease in hydrogen yields. It is believed that at higher catalyst loadings, the solution may become turbid and which can prevent the absorption of incident light by obstructing the light path to reach the catalyst. Hence the optimal catalyst amount is ∼5 mg at which effective light utilization is occurring and consequently higher H2 yields are obtained using the 50 mL reactor pot [61].

The hydrogen production rate is increased with increasing methanol concentration up to 5%. Above 5% (v/v) CH3OH concentration, the hydrogen yields are decreased probably due to higher amount of methanol molecules possibly covered the catalyst surface (Fig. S11). Nevertheless, generation of reactive species on the catalyst surface does not vary because the incident light intensity and the amount of the catalyst used in the reaction were same. At lower volume of CH3OH (2.5 vol%) a lower H2 yield was observed presumably due to lower mass transfer rates of CH3OH on to the catalyst surface [62]. However in both the cases using CH3OH as a sacrificial agent; the H2 yields are enormously increased to 35.4 mmols g-1 h-1 over 2Cu-5Ni-TiO2 catalyst (Table 2). It is a known fact that Cu° in comparison with other oxidation states of copper have the highest effect in the photo catalytic activity and oxidation of copper to Cu+ and Cu2+ lead to a decrease in the photo catalytic activity. Also, the amount of bulk defects which are potential recombination centres of electron-hole pairs decreases with increasing the calcination temperature. Therefore, an appropriate calcination temperature is necessary for reaching to highest photo catalytic activity. It can be seen that the calcination temperature has a significant effect on the photo catalytic activity of 2Cu-5Ni-TiO2 catalyst, wherein it reaches a maximum H2 yield on the sample calcined at 450 °C (Fig. S12). These results also indicated that the photo catalytic activity decreases with increasing of calcination temperature above 450 °C. This behaviour can be explained due an increase in crystallite size of particles or/and agglomeration of nano particles consequently leads to reduction of amount of adsorbed H2O/CH3OH and it is likely that transformation of anatase to the rutile phase at higher calcination temperatures.

The 2Cu/TiO2, 5Ni/TiO2 and 2Cu-5Ni-/TiO2 photocatalysts evaluated in methanol + water mixtures under the natural and artificial sunlight showed more or less similar H2 production rates while compared among. However, the H2 yields over bimetallic catalysts are much higher than their individual counter parts. The high H2 rate on bimetallic 2Cu-5Ni/TiO2 is explained due to the enhanced separation of charge carriers of TiO2. UV- Vis DRS spectra of 2Cu-5Ni-TiO2 catalysts clearly showed lesser band gap and a red shift in visible light absorption indicated a strong interaction between Cu and Ni species in the form of Cu-Ni alloy (Fig. 1) [63]. The bimetallic alloy particles interacted with TiO2 showed the ability of absorbing a wide range of wavelengths in the visible light and thus exhibited improved photocatalytic H2O splitting performance by increasing the rate of trapping photo excited electrons from anatase/rutile TiO2 particles. It is believed that Cu-Ni alloy particles seems to store the photo excited electrons effectively, resulted in the minimisation of recombination of the charge carriers during the course of the reaction [64].

The reason for the enhanced H2O splitting performance of 2Cu-5Ni-/TiO2 catalyst can be explained; by the solar light illuminated, initially the UV component (wavelengths smaller than 380 nm) of the light strikes the TiO2 and creates a charge separation on TiO2 subsequently migration of electrons to the metal particles occurrs on the catalyst surface. The UV-Vis DRS (Fig. S5) analysis revealed, Cu addition to Ni reduced the band gap of TiO2 which results the enhancement of the visible light absorption of Ni. Under irradiation condition, the Cu-Ni alloy nano particles acts as light harvester owing to their surface plasmon resonance behavior when the incident light of visible region (Fig. 1).

Based on the H2 yields obtained and the physicochemical characteristics of the catalysts, it is clear that the visible light excitation by copper-nickel alloy plasmon particles and the UV light excitation of TiO2 on a Cu-Ni/TiO2 catalyst are the reasons for enhanced photocatalytic H2O splitting to produce hydrogen. The solar light is illuminated over Cu-Ni/TiO2 catalyst surface, the TiO2 absorbs the UV light component of the sunlight and it transfer valance band (VB) electrons to the conduction band (CB); simultaneously, the newly generated electrons in CB are transferred to Cu-Ni nano particles which are closely interacted with TiO2 surface (Scheme 1 ). Another possibility can be explained by creation of sub-band states in the band gap of TiO2 by the addition of copper and/or nickel this could have led to create higher number of electron-holes as a result Cu-Ni particles interacted with TiO2 acts as a better trap consequently showing redox property for a significant improvement in the photocatalytic performance.

The UV-DR spectra of used 2Cu-5Ni/TiO2 catalyst displayed (Fig. 1) the typical absorption band with onset 390 nm corresponding to the electronic inter band transition in TiO2 (optical band gap 3.2 eV). These spectra also showed formation of two different compositions of Cu-Ni bands centered at 448-462 nm assigned to the absorption of Ni-Cu2O particles and the other absorption feature at 725-738 nm assigned to Cu-Ni alloy (Fig. S6) [53,65]. During the course of photocatalytic process, first the copper ions are reduced followed by nickel ion species consequently Cu-Ni alloy nanoparticles (NPs) are formed. It is noteworthy to mention that the standard reduction potential for Ni(II)/Ni is -0.257 V and for Cu (II)/Cu is 0.342 V; hence the reducibility Cu (II) ions is higher than Ni (II) ions [66,67]. The H2-TPR analysis has further substantiated this phenomenon of interaction between nickel and copper particles where in the Tmax of Cu-Ni/TiO2 sample was lying between Cu (Tmax) and Ni (Tmax) (Fig. 4, Table 1). A drastic decrease in band gap energies in the photo reduced/used catalysts is a clear indication of Cu-Ni alloy formation (Table 1). The differences in Cu-Ni inter-metallic composition may be a reason for the appearance of two plasmonic bands which were red-shifted to 462 nm and 738 nm (Fig. 1). This behavior is an indication that copper and nickel start to form alloy with different compositions i.e., Ni-Cu2O, Cu-Ni alloy (Fig. S2). Increase in copper loading leads to formation of Cu-Ni alloy nanoparticles which is supplemented by the peak shift around 725-738 nm region (Fig. 1) [68]. N2O titration studies demonstrated the surface metal (Cu and/or Ni) and bimetallic Cu-Ni alloy species are higher in concentration than that are in the photo reduced/used catalysts (Table 1). The extent of photo reduction determined by H2-TPR measurements of fresh calcined and photo reduced samples and the H2 uptake values are reported in Table 1. The Tmax of TPR peaks and corresponding H2 uptakes are drastically decreased, indicating the partial reduction of metal oxides during the course of reaction (photo reduction).

The surface features of Cu and Ni in the fresh and used 2Cu-5Ni/TiO2 catalysts were analyzed by XPS and the corresponding spectra pertaining to O 1s and Ti 2p, Ni 2p and Cu 2p are reported in Fig. S13A and S13B. The spectra of O 1s show two peaks at 529.7 and 531.1 eV, which are related to Ti-O-Ti (lattice oxygen) and -OH (hydroxyl oxygen). The spectra of Ti 2p shows two peaks at 458.9 and 464.8 eV, which belong to Ti 2p3/2 and Ti 2p1/2. The observed spin-orbit splitting between the Ti 2p3/2 and Ti 2p1/2 is 5.9 eV, in good agreement with the value of Ti4+state in TiO2. The XP spectra of the fresh 2Cu-5Ni/TiO2 catalyst exhibited signals at binding energies ∼934.3 and 954.5 eV are attributed to Cu 2p3/2 and Cu2p1/2 indicating the presence of Cu2+ species (Fig. S13A). It is unlikely to expect the Cu1+ species in the fresh form of catalysts which were obtained after the calcination in air unless otherwise mentioned. In the post-reaction/used catalyst, the Cu binding energies are slightly shifted towards lower binding energies (∼932.5 and 953.0 eV; Fig. S13B), compared to that of the fresh catalyst, which indicates the photo reduction of certain portion of copper on the catalyst surface. Since these binding energy values are very close to Cu0 and Cu1+; we have extended the characterization of the used catalyst to exemplify the state of copper by CO pulse chemisorption. It can be understood that the reduction of Cu2+ is a sequential phenomenon where in the first step; the Cu2+ undergo reduction to Cu1+ and then the Cu1+ will be reduced to Cu0 in the second step. Hence there could be a possibility of some portion of Cu1+ existence while retrieving the used catalyst.

The bulk and surface reducible species estimated from H2-TPR and N2O titration results clearly emphasized that about 80% of surface oxides were under reduced form and an average of 50% reduced species were in the bulk after light exposure. A change in electronic and structural properties of the bimetallic samples occurred due to an interaction between Cu-Ni particles and the metal oxide species were photo reduced to some extent during the illumination process [54].

The strong interaction between copper and nickel particles are observed in the H2-TPR analysis which showed a dramatic shift in reduction temperature of NiO from 475 °C (in fresh 5Ni/TiO2) to 400 °C (in the used 5Ni/TiO2) and from 275 °C to 190-222 °C over the used 2Cu/TiO2 catalyst. The low temperature peak attributed to copper oxide reduction in the region 245-290 °C (in fresh 2Cu-5Ni/TiO2) to 222 °C and the high temperature reduction signal ascribed to NiO reduction peak shifted from 455 to 325 °C. The shift in lower temperature reduction peak is explained due to strong interaction between CuO and NiO particles and these were photo reduced to form Cu-Ni alloy during the course of reaction.

In the fresh catalysts CuO and NiO species and CuO and/or NiO along with Cu-Ni alloy species in the post reaction/used 2Cu-5Ni-TiO2 catalyst is observed. The presence of metallic Cu and metallic Ni was estimated by N2O titration and the results are reported in Table 1. About 17% of Cu° and 21.9% of Ni° is present in the used 2Cu/TiO2 5Ni/TiO2 catalysts respectively. To identify the state of surface nickel in the 2Cu-5Ni-TiO2 used catalyst, we have examined it by H2 pulse chemisorption as we recently established the estimation of surface metallic Cu, metallic Ni and the extent of surface Cu-Ni alloy composition using two probe molecules such as N2O titration at 90 °C and H2 adsorption at 50 °C. Neither surface Cu° and/or Cu1+ nor Cu-Ni alloy adsorb H2 at 50 °C [52]. A very low amount of about ∼0.0011 cc / gcat of H2 uptake was observed over used 2Cu-5Ni-TiO2 catalyst. This uptake is due to the segregated metallic Ni present on the catalyst surface. This H2 uptake ∼0.05 × 10-6 mol (gcat)-1 which is equivalent to 0.3% of segregated Ni considering the total N2O uptake (contributed from both copper + nickel) suggesting that most of the reduced Ni is in the form of alloy with Cu. Although the diffraction lines are very weak due to Cu-Ni but a Ni-rich Cu-Ni alloy is observed. Formation of alloy was clearly seen in the H2-TPR analysis where in the Tmax shifted to lower temperatures as well a decrease in the H2 uptakes (Table 1). We could not consider the H2 uptakes from the H2-TPR analysis for the accountability in emphasizing the surface species as TPR is a bulk technique. The diffraction line intensities due to Cu1+ (Cu2O-Ni) species are very weak; so we extended the characterization of the catalysts by other techniques such as XPS, UV-DRS, PL, CO and/or H2 pulse chemisorption.

As such the used catalysts were degassed at 150 °C and then analysed by N2O titration technique in order to estimate the number of reduced copper species during the course of reaction (i.e. photo reduction) (Table 1). The N2O uptake can be due to both the Cu1+ and/or Cu° species present on the catalyst surface since both these species are titrated by N2O whereas the Cu2+ cannot. It has been observed that the N2O uptake was decreased from 28.6 × 10-6 to 4.9 × 10-6 mol g-1 in 2Cu/TiO2 and 94.0 × 10-6 to 20.9 × 10-6 mol g-1 over 2Cu-5Ni/TiO2 catalysts (Table 1). The decrease in N2O uptake clearly suggests that certain portion of surface copper was reduced during the course of reaction. While compared these mono and bimetallic catalysts an enhanced photo reduction was occurred over the bimetallic 2Cu-5Ni/TiO2 catalyst. From the N2O titration data it can be explained that about 17% of Cu° and 21.9% of Ni° is present in the used 2Cu/TiO2, 5Ni/TiO2 catalysts respectively and 22.2% of surface copper was reduced to either Cu° and/or Cu1+. It is difficult to distinguish the Cu° and Cu1+ species exactly from XPS analysis since their binding energy values are close so we then analysed the sample by PL spectroscopy.

The presence of Cu1+ species can be clearly distinguished by photoluminescence spectroscopy. The Cu1+ species generally shows two prominent bands at 480 and 540 nm [69,70]. The photoluminescence spectroscopic analysis of both calcined and used samples showed an extended peak tail at emission bands 480 and 540 nm. It is difficult to mark these signals to Cu1+ since these bands were also found in both the TiO2, 5Ni/TiO2 of fresh and used samples (Fig. 5a, c).

The used bimetallic catalysts were further analysed by UV-DRS spectroscopy and the results are presented in Fig. S14. The absorption band around 446 nm is ascribed to the Cu1+ species and the absorption tail extends to higher wavelength, which is explained due to strong interaction between Cu and Ni in reduced states. One can’t rule out the existence of Cu1+ (which may be there in a smaller quantity) as the Cu2+ reduction is a sequential step up to Cu0. So, to further evaluate the existence of Cu1+ we have tried to examine the Cu1+ species following the reports published by YY Huang [71] and Iwamoto et al [72] which states that CO adsorption occurs on surface Cu1+ species only while Cu2+ and Cu0 can not.

The pulse chemisorption result showed about 0.0124 cc / (gcat) of CO uptake (∼0.55 × 10-6 moles / gcat of CO Table 1) was observed over the used 2Cu-5Ni-TiO2 catalyst, which corresponds to surface Cu1+ species. The total N2O uptake on 2Cu/TiO2 is found to be 4.9 × 10-6 moles / gcat and 20.9 × 10-6 moles / gcat on 2Cu-5Ni-TiO2 catalysts (Table 1). The N2O uptake (4.9 × 10-6 moles / gcat) due to Cu° and partially reduced Cu1+ and considering the CO uptake due to Cu1+ on the 2Cu-5Ni-TiO2 catalyst, about 11.2% of Cu1+ may be present on the used catalyst surface. The N2O uptakes are found to be 15.2 × 10-6 moles / gcat and 20.9 × 10-6 moles / gcat over 5Ni-TiO2 and 2Cu-5Ni-TiO2 catalysts respectively. Considering these values, roughly 9.65% of Cu1+ can be expected. From these results, we can summarize that, on an average about 10% of Cu1+ and 90% of Cu° species are present on the used 2Cu-5Ni-TiO2 catalyst.

However, it should be mentioned here that the segregated surface Ni° can also interfere while estimating the Cu1+ by CO adsorption as CO could also be adsorbed on surface Ni°. Hence, the surface Ni° in the 2Cu-5Ni-TiO2 used catalyst was estimated by H2 pulse chemisorption. A very low amount of about ∼0.0011 cc / gcat of H2 uptake was observed over the used 2Cu-5Ni-TiO2 catalyst. This uptake is due to the segregated Ni° present on the catalyst surface, which is ∼0.05 × 10-6 mol (gcat)-1 and is equivalent to 0.3% of segregated Ni considering the total N2O uptake (contributed from both copper and nickel) suggesting that most of the reduced Ni is in the form of an alloy with Cu. From these results, it can be summarized that the Cu2+ species in the fresh catalyst was reduced to Cu1+-Cu° (10:90) during the course of the reaction emphasizing the existence of Cu2+/(Cu1+-Cu°) heterojunctions on the catalyst surface. These results are in good correlation with the Sinatra et al [73] and Dubale et al [74] findings on hetero structured Cu2O/CuO and Au/Cu2O-TiO2 catalysts.

During the illumination process, both copper and nickel particles were reduced to form a Cu-Ni alloy on TiO2 (Fig. 4B) and the surface Cu-Ni alloy composition was increased with an increase in Cu loading (Table 1). The extent of photo reduction (during the illumination process) was estimated by N2O titration data and the occurrence of photo reduction was observed from the XRD patterns. The N2O titration data also showed a slightly higher photo reduction occurred on 2Cu-5Ni/TiO2 when compared to other Cu loadings, emphasizing the higher number of Cu-Ni alloy particles on the catalyst surface (Table 1). The band around 446 nm assigned to Cu1+ species in a CuO matrix (Fig. 1) was contributed by electron transfer from the valence band of TiO2 to that of CuxO clusters around TiO2 i.e. the inter valence charge transfer (IVCT) [75,76]. The broad absorption hump between 450 and 800 nm in all the samples is due to the d-d electronic transition of Cu2+ [77]. The peaks that appeared around 600-800 nm in the DRS of Cu-Ni/TiO2 catalysts differ from the superposition of DR spectra of 5Ni/TiO2 and 2Cu/TiO2 (Fig. 1) revealing that Ni and/or Cu particles are in close contact with TiO2.

The FT-IR spectra of mono and bimetallic samples are reported in Fig. S15. The IR band observed from 400 to 900 cm-1corresponds to the Ti–O stretching vibrations. On the other hand, the absorption band at 1383 cm-1 which is attributed to the presence of nitrate (NO3-) group, could not be detected in the spectra, indicating that the calcination process was able to completely remove the NO3- group from the raw catalysts. These results strongly confirm the presence of the hydroxyl group in the structure of the samples. The surface hydroxyl groups on TiO2 have been recognized to play an important role in the photocatalytic reaction since they can inhibit the recombination of photo-generated charges and interact with photo-generated holes to produce active oxygen species. The peak at 2343 cm−1 is assigned to the asymmetric stretching of CO2 molecules adsorbed on the surface of the catalyst.

The used samples (photo reduced) such as 5Ni/TiO2 and 2Cu/TiO2 (Fig. S6) demonstrated surface plasmonic resonance (SPR) signals at 721 and 678 nm respectively [78,79]. On the other hand, the bimetallic 2Cu-5Ni/TiO2 sample exhibited its SPR signal at 738 nm, which is entirely different from its mono metallic counterparts. Moreover, the SPR band intensity of the 2Cu-5Ni/TiO2 sample varied with irradiation time and the position of SPR signal red shifted (Fig. S6) with irradiation time. These results were further supplemented by the XRD analysis of the used catalysts and by N2O titration data (Fig. S2 and Table 1). In case of Cu-Ni/TiO2 catalyst, it is believed that the Ni-Cu alloy species which closely interact with TiO2 created additional active species by generating the new energy levels. It is a known fact that the work functions of Ni and Cu are 5.15 eV and 4.94 eV respectively, and it is widely accepted that the work function of Ni-Cu alloy would be lies in between the Ni and Cu [80]. Thus, the newly generated energy levels decrease the height of the Schottky barrier between metal (Ni-Cu alloy) and TiO2. In such an environment, the recombination of photo generated electron-hole pair can be suppressed and electron transfer from TiO2 to Cu-Ni alloy would be enhanced [81]. Thus, the enhanced catalytic performance of the bimetallic Cu-Ni/TiO2 catalyst can be explained due to the tailoring of the catalyst structure in terms of fine tuning of energy levels (Scheme 1) and physicochemical properties. The Cu-Ni alloy formation is further illustrated from the reduction of confined CuO-NiO mixed metal oxide peak at 270 °C in TPR analysis (Fig. 4). The enhanced H2 production rate of the Cu-Ni/TiO2 sample is mainly depend on the plasmonic activation of Cu-Ni alloy nano-species in the presence of sunlight. Over the past decade, revived strategies have been adopted in the synthesis of modified TiO2 so as to generate additional surface defects/active sites for improved hydrogen yields by doping various base and noble metal catalysts in order, firstly, to avoid the use of a co-catalyst and secondly, to generate the p-n hetero junctions.

A comparative analysis of the hydrogen production rates reported by various authors is summarized in Table S1. For example, Tian et al reported a H2 production rate of 13.5 mmol h−1 g−1 over Cu and Ni co-modified TiO2 nanoparticles [82]. The bimetallic Pd-Pt supported on nano titanate produced about 12.4 mmol/gcat of hydrogen [83]. Using Au-Ag/TiO2 catalyst, Patra and Gopinath demonstrated hydrogen yields of up to 0.72 mmol h−1 g−1 [84]. Weng et al developed a method of synthesis of ultrafine TiO2 nano sheets in combination with C hetero junctions that showed increased hydrogen yields under super critical water [85]. The core-shell Ag/Ni/TiO2 catalysts reported by Gao et al demonstrated a hydrogen rate of 2.93 mmol h−1 g−1 and the synergy was explained due to the strong interaction between silver and nickel nano particles [86]. In a recent study, Martinez et al established the effect of morphology of Cu-Au alloy nano particles which showed a hydrogen production rate of 16.2 mmol h−1 g−1 [87]. The surface structure of the photocatalyst was altered by varying catalyst synthesis methodologies e.g. doping of nitrogen in to TiO2 lattice was reported by Esmat et al over anatase TiO2 nano sheets [88]. We found the photo reduction of the catalyst during the course of reaction, which was supported by UV-DRS, PL, XPS, XRD, N2O titration, CO and/or H2 chemisorption results. Upon irradiation, the surface Cu, Ni and/or Cu-Ni nano alloy sites become active in the UV-vis region. A drastic decrease in the PL intensity of used catalysts emphasizes the enhanced charge separation of electron and hole in the presence of Ni-Cu alloy nanoparticles on the TiO2 surface. Surface defects, such as oxygen vacancies in TiO2 particles, and the synergetic interaction of bimetallic Cu-Ni alloy, played an important role in improving the photocatalytic performance of Cu-Ni/TiO2. What is primarily required is to disturb the crystal lattice of TiO2. By introducing Cu and/or Ni oxides, the extended light absorption of TiO2 from the UV to the visible range was observed as the oxygen vacancies give rise to local states below the conduction band edge. The Cu-Ni alloy species seems to alter the electronic transitions, resulted in the improvement in the separation of the photo induced charge carriers (electrons and holes) on the catalyst surface as was evidenced from the lower PL intensity. In general, presence of a high ratio of surface defects and/or surface oxygen vacancies leads to the localization of valence and conduction bands. These factors are responsible for a decrease in PL intensity in the photo reduced 2Cu-5Ni/TiO2 catalysts. Such oxygen vacancies can greatly influence the photo induced charge behaviour. Consequently 35.4 mmol g−1 h−1 hydrogen yield is observed over bimetallic catalysts than over their monometallic counterparts. The driving force for the improved H2 yields is explained due to the presence of hetero junctions such as Cu2+/(Cu1+-Cu0) species in close proximity to the surface nickel interacted with TiO2 particles.

Scheme 1, represents the plasmonically activated Cu-Ni alloy species in presence of sunlight, transfer their electrons to the holes present on the valence band of TiO2 [89]. In the meantime, the created holes can be able to oxidise methanol and H+ species would be reduced by the electrons of the conduction band which are present on the catalyst surface. It is believed that the binary Cu-Ni/TiO2 catalyst would efficiently reduce the H+ with respect to their mono metallic catalysts [90]. The synergism existed between Cu and Ni and the catalytic cycles work in concert to generate a single new entity i.e., the Cu-Ni alloy an active phase possessed the plasmonic band (a powerful new mechanistic approach to reaction band engineering) for the visible light activated catalyst for the production of H2 by photocatalytic water splitting. Thus, modification of TiO2 using bimetallic systems created plasmonic resonance behaviour which is advantageous over their mono-metallic counterparts. The present study clearly demonstrated the changes in electronic properties observed over an optimized composition of 2Cu-5Ni/TiO2 photocatalyst that showed an improved H2 yield.

The mono and bimetallic Cu-Ni loaded TiO2 nanoparticles have been examined for photocatalytic water splitting by irradiating natural and artificial sunlight using methanol + water mixture. XRD patterns of these catalysts indicated the combination of rutile and anatase phases and the CuO and NiO species were finely dispersed on the TiO2 surface. The reduction profiles of fresh samples showed peaks attributed to copper oxide, nickel oxide and mixed oxides of nickel and copper. The photo reduced Cu-Ni alloy nanoparticles showed a strong photo response under sunlight in the 400-800 nm region was due to surface plasmon resonance, which was accomplished due to an alloying effect between Cu and Ni species. As a result, excellent electron-hole separation and increased lifetime of the electron occurred. The high photocatalytic activity is resulted from the effective usage of a higher portion of visible light photons. The Ni and Cu alloy species present in the bimetallic catalyst demonstrated a higher electron trapping capacity during its photo excitation due to which minimisation of electron hole separation occurred under sunlight irradiation, consequently produced the significantly improved H2 yields in photocatalytic H2O splitting.

M. Kotesh Kumar: Activity studies, Mapping studies, H2 and CO adsorption studies. G. Naresh: N2O titration, XPS analysis. V. Vijay Kumar: Catalyst synthesis, H2-TPR. B. Sai Vasista: TEM. B. Sasikumar: UV-DRS, XRD. A. Venugopal: Planning, execution, writing manuscript and PhD supervisor to M. Kotesh Kumar.
